conversations.content: You are a skilled librarian specialized in meticulous cataloguing of digital documents.

Task: Extract metadata from a single document and return STRICT JSON ONLY (no prose, no markdown fences, do NOT return the input).

Schema (keys + expectations):
{
  "title": string | null,
  "subtitle": string | null,
  "publication_year": integer | null,            // 4-digit year, e.g., 2022
  "language_as_iso639-2": string | null,         // 3-letter ISO 639-2 code (e.g., "dan", "eng")
  "identifiers": {
    "ISBN": string | null                        // preserve hyphens if present; do not fabricate
  },
  "publisher": string[],                         // array of publisher names; [] if none
  "creator_persons": string[],                   // array of person strings exactly as in text (with roles in []); [] if none
  "creator_corporations": string[],              // array of corporations strings exactly as in text (with roles in []); [] if none
  "country_of_publication_iso639-1": string[],   // 2-letter lowercase ISO 3166-1 codes (e.g., "dk", "se"); [] if unknown
  "series": string[],                            // array of series titles; [] if none
  "series_number": string[]                      // array of series numbering values as strings; [] if none
}

Rules:
- Output ONLY the JSON object with all top-level keys and the "identifiers" key with the subkey "ISBN".
- Do NOT include any extra keys, comments, or text.
- Use null for unknown scalar fields; [] for unknown arrays; {"ISBN": null} if ISBN is missing.
- Normalize:
  - publication_year: single 4-digit year (prefer explicit publication cues).
  - language_as_iso639-2: valid lowercase 3-letter code.
  - country_of_publication_iso639-1: valid lowercase 2-letter codes.
- Do NOT hallucinate values. If multiple possible values exist, choose the one most clearly marked as publication metadata.
- Preserve diacritics in titles/names. Trim whitespace.
- Preserve creator order as in source.

Now process the input strictly per these rules and return the JSON object.

Input:
:\n\nTITLE PAGE:\nNational Water Stewardship Outlook\nA Strategic Assessment for Sustainable Catchment Management

\nPublication Year: 2023\nPrepared by: Mara Vintrell (Author)\nEdited by: Orun Hale\n
Published by the Bureau of Public Utilities\nIn collaboration with the Hydrology Planning Office\
nISBN: 000-0-0000001-0\nT:\n1.
Introduction\nSustaining catchment systems requires coordinated planning, adaptive monitoring,
and a shared commitment to preserving watershed integrity.
This Outlook provides a forward-looking framework for evaluating stress factors, infrastructure performance,
and management readiness across diverse hydrologic regions.\n\n2. Methodological Notes\nAssessment indicators were
selected based on resilience modeling, sediment-flow simulations, and community-derived stewardship priorities.
Data inputs were synthetically generated for illustrative planning scenarios.\n\n3. Catchment Condition
 Summary\nAcross surveyed basins, projected flow variability increases by 12â€“27% under stress-test models.
 Governance readiness ratings trend moderate, with notable gaps in long-horizon maintenance funding.

4. Strategic Recommendations\nKey actions include enhancing real-time monitoring networks,

{"title": "National Water Stewardship Outlook", "subtitle": "A Strategic Assessment for Sustainable Catchment Management", "publication_year": 2023, "language_as_iso639-2": "eng", "identifiers": {"ISBN": "000-0-0000001-0"}, "publisher": ["Bureau of Public Utilities"], "creator_persons": ["Mara Vintrell [author]", "Orun Hale [editor]"], "creator_corporations": ["Hydrology Planning Office"], "country_of_publication_iso639-1": ["us"]}

Input:
Aotearoa Cultural Heritage Digitisation Report Progress and Future Directions for National Preservation

nExecutive Summary national preservation initiatives continue expanding synthetic modelling indicates accelerated growth
digitisation workflows with increased resilience in distributed archival nodes\nSection 1 Programme Scope report outlines
 fictional nationwide digitisation scenarios incorporating manuscript imaging audio restoration and metadata enrichment pipelines
 \nSection 2
 Infrastructure Readiness assessment suggests moderate readiness across regional hubs highlighting gaps in
  long term storage redundancy and cross platform integration\nSection 3 Future Directions synthetic projections
   emphasise benefits of expanded community digitisation partnerships distributed quality assurance teams and adaptive preservation standards",
New Zealand Heritage Office ISBN 000 0 0000004 0\
 2021 Mereana Raukawa Digital Aotearoa Programme Te Tari Taonga Aotearoa

Environmental Risk Advisory Projected Impacts of Coastal Erosion
Talin Ores Geospatial Analysis Centre
2024 Ministry for Ecological Safeguards


 nIntro synthetic projections portray increased erosion pressure zones with fluctuating retreat bands influenced
  by modeled storm surge recurrence intervals\nSection 1 Shoreform Dynamics fictional cliff face models show
  uplift sensitive units prone to accelerated degradation in multi year cycles\nSection 2 Asset Impacts risk
  matrices reveal escalating exposure for modeled public amenities including parks pathways and coastal utilities\n
  Section 3 Policy Guidance synthetic recommendations encourage adaptive zoning iterative hazard review cycles and
   multi agency shoreline monitoring"

"Public Infrastructure Audit Summary Condition and Maintenance Needs Assessment
2023 Fenric Dol Civil Asset Review Office Infrastructure Oversight Board ISBN 000 0 0000006 0\n\
nExecutive Summary   synthetic inspection data suggests varying degradation rates across modeled transport corridors
   with several regions showing accelerated wear on drainage grates and pedestrian surfaces\n\n1
    Baseline Conditions  modeled roadway segments present inconsistent surface cohesion
    stray cracking patterns appear in high-use intersections  simulated bridges show moderate joint stress
    \n\n2  Maintenance Forecast   fictional load testing indicates  short term interventions may stabilize most span structures
     but long-term resurfacing cycles likely required sooner than expected\n\n3 Recommendations
     proposed synthetic actions include staggered maintenance blocks   distributed inspection shifts  and
     consolidated reporting protocols to reduce lag in hazard detection",

Input:
National Energy Transition White Paper explores modeled pathway scenarios for shifting fictional national grids toward
 diversified renewable portfolios   synthetic projections indicate variable adoption rates among regional load zones
 with intermittency buffers showing mixed performance under stress-test cycles
 Scenario Framework   energy mixes constructed from artificial datasets suggest moderate gains
  in stability when distributed storage nodes are paired with adaptive dispatch algorithms
  Infrastructure Resilience
  simulated grid segments present uneven tolerance to peak-demand fluctuations
  older substations show accelerated thermal fatigue in multi-cycle tests
  Policy Levers
  synthetic policy modeling favors phased incentive curves   targeted grid-hardening protocols
   and iterative compliance reviews to maintain trajectory alignment\n\n
   National Energy Transition White Paper 2024
    Luri Sen
     Green Systems Laboratory
     Energy Transition Secretariat

      Ona Relik  Scholarly Standards Unit  Council for Academic Evaluation  2022\n

      Intro
Modeled performance indicators demonstrate gradual improvement in instructional coherence although disparities
       remain between simulated academic divisions
\n
1 Programme Evaluation Methods fictional benchmark tools applied
        across synthetic institutions highlight misaligned assessment criteria and uneven workload calibration\n
2 Staff Capability Profiles synthetic survey constructs suggest moderate preparedness for competency-based instruction
        yet reveal limited adoption of adaptive teaching cycles\n

          periodic standards mapping   and broadened evidence-collection practices",
